Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan
What: Announced the start of administering COVID-19 immunizations to children 5 to 11 years in Regina and Saskatoon and expanding to other communities and regions through the week
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan
What: Announced the expansion of the free rapid test kit program to 41 Co-op locations across the province through a partnership between the Saskatchewan Public Safety Agency and Federated Co-operatives Limited 
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan 
What: Increased eligibility for 3rd doses and reduced interval from 6 to 5 months for the following groups: individuals age 50 and older, individuals 18 years and older living in the far north and those living on First Nation communities, all health care workers and those born in 2009 or earlier with specific underlying health conditions (e.g., diabetes)
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan 
What: Announced all individuals 18 years or older are eligible for a booster vaccine 3 months from their 2nd dose
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan 
What: Announced asymptomatic residents who receive a positive COVID-19 result on a rapid antigen test will no longer be recommended to receive a confirmatory PCR test
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan 
What: Announced fully vaccinated asymptomatic residents who receive a positive COVID-19 result on a rapid antigen test or PCR test will be required to self-isolate for 5 days, down from 10 days
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan
What: Announced all individuals who are moderately to severely immunocompromised and have had 3 doses for their primary COVID-19 vaccination series are eligible to receive a 4th dose at least 3 months after their 3rd dose 
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan
What: Announced schools are updating notification processes for close contacts of someone who tests postive for COVID-19;  notifications will be sent to parents/guardians of the class and/or bus cohort that may be considered close contacts; fully vaccinated students and staff who are close contacts can attend school and other activities as long as they remain asymptomatic; fully vaccinated students and staff who test positive are required to self-isolate for 5 days; non-fully vaccinated students and staff who are close contacts may not come to school and must self-isolate for 10 days following last exposure
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan
What: Announced plans to eliminate COVID-19-related surgical backlogs through performing additional surgeries in 2022–23 over pre-pandemic levels
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan 
What: Announced the availability of new antiviral drug (Paxlovoid) for COVID-19 in the province following a positive test
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan
What: Announced individuals who receive a positive test result on a PCR or rapid antigen test will be required to self-isolate for 5 days from the date of test or 24 hours after fever has resolved, regardless of vaccination status; close contacts of positive COVID-19 cases will no longer be required to self-isolate, regardless of vaccination status
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan
What: Announced parents and caregivers are no longer required to notify schools about positive test results for the purposes of close contact notification; those who test positive are required to self-isolate and will be absent from school and activities for the duration of the self-isolation period
Effective until:

Who: Saskatchewan Health Authority 
What: Developed a Proof of Full COVID-19 Vaccination policy for health care workers; will be implemented in a phased approach
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan 
What: Announced activation of Provincial Command to coordinate pandemic response, ensure resource optimization and provide administrative support so health care workers can better focus on provision of care
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan 
What: Announced temporary fee codes for physicians related to providing vaccinations in a physician's office and counselling unvaccinated patients when the patient is in the office for another service
Effective until:

Who: Minister of Health
What: Extended directive allowing non-traditional immunizers in administering influenza and COVID-19 vaccines
Effective until: 2022-03-31

Who: Government of Saskatchewan, Saskatchewan Health Authority 
What: Announced plans to reduce COVID-19-related surgical backlog by increasing capacity in Saskatchewan Health Authority hospitals and publicly funded private surgical clinics; the government also plans to expand intensive care unit capacity, and will recruit additional nurses and health professionals to meet targets
Effective until:

Who: Saskatchewan Health Authority 
What: Updated the COVID-19 surge plan to address potential staff absenteeism from the Omicron variant; this includes but is not limited to establishing Go Teams of mobile medical professionals and cross training staff
Effective until:

Who: Saskatchewan College of Pharmacy Professionals 
What: Enacted emergency provisions and guidelines for pharmacists authorized to perform COVID-19 rapid antigen testing in pharmacies starting 2022-01-21
Effective until:

Who: Government of Saskatchewan 
What: Hired 95 additional full-time equivalent continuing care assistants in long-term care and home care sectors
Effective until:

Who: Boards of education
What: Winter breaks in Sask. regions follow the same schedule; Saskatoon and Regina schools example provided
Effective until: 2022-01-03

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Issued a strong recommendation that Carcross residents wear a mask in all indoor public spaces
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Issued a strong recommendation for the consistent use of masks in all indoor public spaces throughout the territory
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Announced that proof of full vaccination will be required to access non-essential services in the territory
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Announced 3rd dose (booster) will be available to Yukoners age 50 and older 
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Declared a territorial state of emergency 
Effective until: 2021-12-03

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Announced that masking is mandatory where physical distancing cannot be maintained in all indoor public settings and outdoor public settings
Effective until: 2021-12-03

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Placed limits on gatherings: personal gatherings limited to 10 people from a maximum of 2 households, if vaccinated; organized indoor gatherings limited to 25 with proof of vaccination, and outdoor limited to 50 individuals; faith-based and cultural gatherings have a maximum capacity of 50% with proof of vaccination
Effective until: 2021-12-03

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Restaurant, bar and nightclub patrons will be required to provide proof of vaccination for table service, with a limit of 6 individuals per table, no counter service and no dancing; personal services will also require proof of vaccination 
Effective until: 2021-12-03

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Gyms, fitness and yoga studios prohibited to have high-intensity fitness classes; proof of vaccination required for low-intensity classes and organized sports
Effective until: 2021-12-03

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Recommends that schools remain open with new measures to include students masking when in classrooms and at desks and that activities between schools to be suspended
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon, Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Required that people age 12 and older provide proof of vaccination to access designated establishments and services in the province
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Released the Yukon Vaccination Verifier app to help designated services and establishments verify proof of vaccination credentials
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Children age 5 to 11 will be able to book at vaccination clinics starting 2021-12-06
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Changed the vaccine verification requirements for youth under the age of 18: government-issued identification that does not include a photograph may now be shown along with proof of vaccination for youth age 12 to 17 to access designated settings; youth had previously been required to show government-issued photo identification
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health, Government of Yukon
What: Removed the proof of vaccination requirement for sport and recreation activities for those under 19
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health, Government of Yukon
What: Eased limitations on gatherings: indoor gatherings will no longer be limited to 25 individuals, but limited to 50% capacity and masking, and outdoor gatherings no longer limited to 50 people; indoor personal gatherings are also no longer limited to 2 households 
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Advised Yukoners not to travel outside of Canada and cautioned against travel within Canada
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Updated the territory's testing procedures to change eligibility for access to PCR testing to those who are at most risk of getting sick 
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health, Government of Yukon
What: Tightened limitations on gatherings: indoor personal gatherings can have 10 people from a maximum of 2 households if all eligible people over 12 years and 4 months are vaccinated, household members only if unvaccinated; unvaccinated individuals who live alone can gather with a maximum of 1 additional household and a maximum of 10 people; outdoor personal gatherings may only have 15 people from a maximum of 3 households regardless of vaccination status; organized gatherings must be limited to 25 people or 50% of venue capacity for indoor gatherings and 50 people for outdoor gatherings; faith-based services are also restricted to 25 people or 50% of venue capacity and proof of vaccination
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health, Government of Yukon
What: Announced proof of vaccination required for table service for those age 19 and older, with a limit of 6 people per table, tables to be spaced 2 metres apart, no bar or counter eating, no dancing; in businesses and retail locations, a maximum of 50% capacity in place; personal services establishments require proof of vaccination, limited to 25 people or 50% of venue capacity 
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health, Government of Yukon
What: Announced that for entertainment venues, leisure sites, sports facilities, gyms and recreational team sports, proof of vaccination required, capacity lowered to 25 people or 50% of venue capacity; for team sports, no games between teams, activities within cohort or team limited to 25 people
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Amended criteria for accessing rapid antigen tests, to allow those who are symptomatic who do not meet the requirements for a PCR test
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Recommended that Yukoners returning from domestic travel monitor for symptoms and self-isolate when sick
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Announced the limiting of all private and public gatherings to 2 households and a maximum of 10 people; additionally, all indoor organized events, including funerals and weddings, are postponed
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Announced that bars and restaurants are to close no later than 10 p.m. and the limit of 6 people per table is still in effect
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Announced that proof of vaccination is required for table service for those 12 years and 4 months of age and older and no seated or dine-in service past 10 p.m., but takeout will be offered to normal closing times; proof of vaccination not required for takeout services
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Announced that recreation and leisure sites will require proof of vaccination for those 12 and older; organized events and class attendance limited to 10 people from a maximum of 2 households; no indoor team games or practices permitted, except for up to 10 people from a maximum of 2 households playing together 
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Schools and licensed early learning and child care programs in rural Yukon will receive 2,800 rapid tests; tests will be available for pickup at schools during normal school hours; tests cannot be sent home with students as they must not freeze
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Limited eligibility for PCR tests to those who are most at risk of getting very sick from COVID-19
Effective until:

Who: Chief Medical Officer of Health
What: Booster shot (3rd dose) appointments now available for Yukoners age 18 and older
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Announced mandatory vaccination requirements for health care workers: employees will have until 2021-11-30 to receive 2 doses of vaccine
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Updated mandatory vaccine requirements for health care workers: employees required to have their 1st dose of vaccine no later than 2021-11-30 and their 2nd dose no later than 2022-01-30
Effective until:

Who: Government of Yukon
What: Temporary restrictions for restaurants, bars and nightclubs lifted; proof of vaccination for personal care services no longer required
Effective until:

Who: Yukon schools
What: Winter breaks in Y.T. vary by region
Effective until: 2022-01-03
